name: Alt-Country
description: Arose in the 1980s and 1990s, performed by artists with roots in Alternative Rock and Indie Rock who were disconnected from the mainstream Country industry.

children.name: Gothic Country
children.description: Evokes the Southern Gothic literary genre through morbid lyrical themes and melancholic sounds that emphasize its American Folk Music and Post-Punk influences.

name: Bluegrass
description: Born in the Appalachian region of the United States during the late 1930s, characterized by fingerpicked banjo along with other traditional instruments.

children.name: Bluegrass Gospel
children.description: Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.

children.name: Progressive Bluegrass
children.description: Mixing the sound and aesthetics of pure Bluegrass with a variety of influences outside of its Appalachian origins, including Jazz, Folk, Rock, and other forms of Country.

children.name: Jamgrass
children.description: Emphasizes instrumental jamming and extended performances with many outside influences.

name: Contemporary Country
description: Incorporates both heavily Pop-influenced styles, and the more pop-averse movement of Neo-Traditionalist Country.

children.name: Neo-Traditionalist Country
children.description: Emerged in the late 1980s as a reaction to the increased dominance of Country Pop, moving instead towards a Honky Tonk-rooted sound that centered the Singer-Songwriter.

name: Country & Irish
description: Developed in Ireland; combines North American Country with Irish Folk Music influences, often in the form of traditional Irish songs that have been adapted into country numbers.

name: Country Boogie
description: Uptempo style built around the Boogie Woogie rhythm, with strong beats and prominent electric guitar leads, made popular in the 1940s.

name: Country Pop
description: Combination of Country with Pop to appeal to a larger audience.

children.name: Bro-Country
children.description: Originated in the 21st century and takes its cues from Hip Hop, Pop and Contemporary Country.

children.name: Countrypolitan
children.description: Emphasizes Pop-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of Country instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.

children.name: Urban Cowboy
children.description: Melds country and Pop (best described as 70s L.A. soft pop), and sometimes leans towards Disco.

name: Honky Tonk
description: Upbeat style that retains much of the common instrumentation of Traditional Country, as well as featuring prominent guitars (especially the steel guitar), strong backbeats and lyrics commonly about the working-class life.

children.name: Bakersfield Sound
children.description: Country based heavily on electric instrumentation and a defined backbeat.

children.name: Truck Driving Country
children.description: Derived from Honky Tonk, Country Rock and Bakersfield Sound; aimed at the truck driving community.

name: Nashville Sound
description: Production style characterized by smooth vocals over a relaxed ensemble of guitars and rhythm section, and variously incorporating elements from other styles of Country and Pop.

children.name: Countrypolitan
children.description: Emphasizes Pop-oriented orchestration and songwriting while reducing the role of Country instrumentation and rhythms; often featuring lush string arrangements and group backing vocals.

name: Progressive Country
description: Blend of traditionalist Country styles with elements of Rock, Contemporary Folk, and other countercultural genres; characterized by realistic, self-reflective lyrics and non-traditional songwriting and production elements.

children.name: Outlaw Country
children.description: Rock-influenced reaction to mainstream Country Pop trends, featuring rebellious personas, darker lyrics, and Western-inspired outlaw imagery.

name: Red Dirt
description: Oklahoman and Texan acts descended from the Stillwater, Oklahoma independent Country scene of the 1980s.

name: Traditional Country
description: Closely aligned with American Folk Music and Blues roots, from country's inception in Appalachia and the American South until the popularity of Honky Tonk and Country Pop in the 1950s.

children.name: Close Harmony
children.description: Traditional two-part harmony singing performed mostly by brothers.

children.name: Country Gospel
children.description: Traditional Country that heavily incorporates Gospel.

children.name: Bluegrass Gospel
children.description: Incorporates the religious topics and harmony vocals found in Country Gospel.

children.name: Country Yodeling
children.description: Vocal technique of Yodeling, brought to the United States by German settlers, sung over the instrumentation of Traditional Country.

name: Western
description: Reflects and portrays the lifestyles of cowboys and other settlers of the Western United States through both Traditional Folk Music and popular song.

name: Western Swing
description: Blend of Traditional Country string instrumentation with the driving rhythms of Jazz and regional dance traditions, often prominently featuring fiddle and steel guitar.
